author: sky.cactus
content: I am pretty sure they exist so we can recover from a consensus failure chain split.

author: sky.cactus
content: e.g., Geth has a bug that causes it to fork away from the rest of the network.  We eventually fix the bug and get a patch out, but it takes a week to get out to everyone.  We want to be sure that people don't have to all resync from scratch once the patch is out.

author: potuz
content: I wander if they make any sense post-merge, specially for clients like geth that are massively a majority client on the execution side: any consensus bug in geth may end up finalizing the "wrong" chain quite quickly, so there won't be any deep reorgs without manual intervention anyway.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: We want to retain the 90k limit in geth anyway in order to support manual interventions

author: potuz
content: The issue is that if there's such a thing as a consensus bug in geth that results in finalizing a wrong fork, presumably no one will want to reorg even manually, unless some drastic measure is taken like rolling back or forgiving slashings.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Yeah exactly, and we want to be able to support these drastic measures

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Otherwise it would not be possible to fix it, since only a couple of archive nodes would have the correct state

author: potuz
content: I wander how this fix would look on the consensus side. Can't think of anything "clean" to do in that case. It feels like the move to PoS increases the pressure on geth quite a bit
